utterances: So the evidence, you know, clinically the evidence is there, and I do disagree that the reason that it was removed from the pharmacopeia, the American Medical Association in 1937, after the introduction of the Cannabis Tax Act, was - stood alone in saying that there is no evidence that cannabis is dangerous and that this act would impede the ability to research it for its effectiveness.
And then it was removed from the pharmacopeia and subjected to Schedule 1, and, you know, the main target in this country's failed war on drugs.
So you think there are not enough resources to conduct the clinical studies that would be needed?
So what was it like to watch those hearings?
Our bodies have been really very careful designed by evolution to ensure that generally we're only going to ovulate one egg a month, maybe two, because one baby is really what we should be carrying.
The uterus is a single occupancy room and not really built for more than 10 pounds of baby.
But she could conceive eight babies, you know, 12 babies, six babies and then is faced with a terrible choice of whether to reduce some of these children.
And if a patient can't bring herself to do that, that's when we see these really, really large multiple births.
And the children are often going to have, you know, serious health problems.
This rise in multiple births that you note in the book, it also converges with another trend.
These children are often born to older women.
That's right.
And IVF, I should say, also contributes to this.
Often doctors, when they transfer embryos - because they don't know which one is going to take - will transfer two or three or four or five.
And so, even with IVF, which is more controlled, half of IVF babies are born as part of a set.
And often it's twins but often it's triplets.
And the older the mother, the more likely she is to be using donor eggs.
Donor eggs usually come from very fertile young women so these embryos are more likely to take.
And as a result, yes, the most rapid increase in multiple births has been among women over 35 and particularly women over 40.
And that is a real health issue.

People think that pregnancy is so safe nowadays, and mercifully it is, but any woman carrying twins or triplets is much more likely to develop preeclampsia, to develop all sorts of serious complications of pregnancy.
And of course, the older the mother is, the more likely she is to develop some serious health problems herself.
Now, you really put a phase on these stories.
In this case, you've been taking about multiples and what multiples mean for women and for couples.
There's a story of Melissa Middleton(ph) and her husband Brent(ph).
Why is that story so important when we pull back the curtain and try to look at reproductive medicine?
Well, this was a couple who just wanted to have a family life.
And they could not afford IVF and so she used fertility drugs alone.
She went to a doctor and she said, you know, I really don't want to have multiples.
And the doctor said oh it's very unlikely that you'll conceive and any more than one.
And I find that really surprising because, in fact, it's quite likely.
And in fact, they conceived quadruplets.
She, like, really, any mother carrying quads went into labor very prematurely.
They initially thought none of the children would survive.
All the children obviously had serious health problems and one of them - actually, the healthiest contracted an infection.
I think it was about 10 days after being born and died in Melissa's arms.
The three other children all came home at various times and which case their home really became a neonatal intensive care unit.
And children born so prematurely are subject to all sorts of afflictions - vision problems, speech delays, you know, physical development issues.
This couple has been just absolutely heroic.
Absolutely heroic and doing everything they can for their children but it's a hard road to haul.
In the spectrum of outcomes using reproductive technologies, how common is this kind of story?
I was just overwhelmed by the numbers of stories I heard like this.

Another woman who conceived triplets through IVF and two of them were actually identical twins and conceived twin to twin transfusion syndrome, which is a serious situation whether twins are sort of sucking nutrients from each other.
It's a hard condition to manage.
And she also ended up delivering very prematurely - in this case so prematurely that the babies were dead and dying as they were being born.
And, I talk about, you know, the choices that couples are faced with.
In this case, her choice was whether she wanted to hold her babies as they were dying.
Liza, these are very difficult stories to hear and I imagine it was difficult for you to report on this and ultimately to write about it.
But if we can sort of scale back, go back to the beginning of this process, for those parent who enter this process with so much hope.
You know, wanting so badly to bare children, did they know about this?
Is this something that doctors warn them about?
I don't think that there's enough warning about the risk of multiples.
And doctors will often say, well, parents want twins and we just can't talk them out of it.

And it's true, studies have been shown that many IVF patients who come into the process, as you say, with a lot of hope and optimism - and I'm so sympathetic to that - they come in thinking, well, I've - this treatment is stressful and I've spent a lot of money now.
And if I could get two children, you know, for the price of one, you could say, and not have to go through an IVF cycle again, that would be a good thing.
And if I get three, you know, that would be okay.
What happens now is that patients make the ultimate choice of how many embryos to transfer.
And I'm really not sure it should work that way.
Who should have the choice if not the patient?
I think that doctors should be a lot more forceful in their recommendations and there are some clinics who now basically say to the patient you don't have a choice anymore.
If you're under 36, it's going to be two.
That's what you get, that's what we do.
What do you think?
Well, I don't think patient have a role in every aspect of their treatment.
I mean, they don't tell the doctor how to perform the heart surgery.

And if we had more insurance coverage of IVF in this country, I think that the insurance companies would come in and say, well, look, we don't want to be paying for the health costs associated with the triplets pregnancy.
You get two embryos this time, and if it doesn't work, we'll pay for a second cycle.
And sure that's not easy for a patient to go through a second cycle but I think there are some forces that could come in to play to reduce the number of embryos.
That was Liza Mundy.
Her book is ""Everything Conceivable: How Assisted Reproduction is Changing Men, Women and the World"".
And you can find an excerpt at our Web site, npr.org.
There's a new car dealership in Saudi Arabia.
All the salesmen are women.
All the customers are women.
Funny thing is, women are not allowed to drive in the kingdom.
They are allowed to own cars, however, as long as they can afford a male chauffer.
The saleswomen at the new showroom in Riyadh can talk carburetors, gearshifts and cylinders, but they insist they're not pushing to get women behind the wheel.
They told the AP their goal is just to sell cars to women who feel uncomfortable haggling over options with a man.
But who doesn't?
You're listening to ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
Terrorists and undercover CIA agents are the stuff of news headlines these days, but they also make for thrilling fiction.
Allen Cheuse has a review of two new spy novels, Alex Berenson's THE FAITHFUL SPY and Robert Baer's BLOW THE HOUSE DOWN.
Maxwell Waller, the main character in BLOW THE HOUSE DOWN, shows a profile much like his creators, longtime CIA field agent with strong ties to the Middle East.

The prologue takes us back to the spring of 1984, when he was stationed in Lebanon and got the news that William Buckley, the CIA station chief in Beirut, had been kidnapped by terrorists and later murdered.
Determined to discover the identity of the leader of that kidnapping operation, Waller, years later, finds some evidence that he makes the mistake of presenting to some of his colleagues.

One of them dies almost immediately, apparently by his own hand, and Waller becomes the subject of surveillance by his own people, which sends him underground, making his way back to the Middle East in pursuit of Buckley's killers.
How all this ties in to the discovery of some U.S.
participants in the 9/11 plot drives this engaging story forward, ever forward to an explosive conclusion.
Quite ironically, the first novel, THE FAITHFUL SPY, by the New York Times reporter Alex Berenson, a man with no experience in the spy trade, stacks up just as well if not better than Baer's.
The spy of the title is a CIA agent named John Wells, who becomes the first American agent to infiltrate alQaida.
Wells, caught between his authentic American loyalty and a newly acquired devotion to Islam, takes us on a stealth mission to infiltrate one of the most tightly bound organizations in the world.
Both books suggest that lone wolves like Maxwell Waller and John Wells are the only variety of agent who can stand between us and a terrorist Armageddon.
That might not be so comforting to think about with respect to real life, but in novels as engrossing as these, it makes for fast and furious fiction of an infectious variety.
The books are THE FAITHFUL SPY by Alex Berenson and BLOW THE HOUSE DOWN by Robert Baer.
Our reviewer, Alan Cheuse, teaches at George Mason University.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Melissa Block.
I'm Robert Siegel.
And we begin with today's big story, the withdrawal of Harriet Miers as a nominee for the Supreme Court.
Miers cited a growing dispute over access to White House documents as the reason for her move, but her nomination faced increasing opposition from the right wing of the president's own party.
We'll have analysis from our legal scholars in a few minutes, but we start our coverage with NPR's David Welna at the Capitol.
Miers hand-delivered President Bush a letter at 8:30 this morning.
It said she no longer wanted to be considered for a nomination in which this president has invested both prestige and a huge amount of political capital.
`I am concerned,' Miers wrote, `that the confirmation process presents a burden for the White House and our staff and is not in the best interests of the country.
The president's spokesman later told reporters that Mr. Bush was, quote, ""deeply disappointed"" in the process that prompted Miers to quit.
On the Senate floor, Republican Majority Leader Bill Frist maintained it was Miers' decision alone to drop out.
I had a conversation with Ms. Miers early this morning and she told me that it was last evening that she spoke to the president and did formally request her nomination to be withdrawn.
Still, pressure was clearly mounting for Miers to bow out.
Frist's spokesman confirmed the Republican leader offered what he called a frank assessment on Miers' standing last night to White House Chief of Staff Andrew Card.
Frist expressed no regret today about Miers' withdrawal, but Democratic Leader Harry Reid did.
I believe without any question when the history books are written about all this that it will show that the radical right wing of the Republican Party drove this woman's nomination right out of town.
Apparently Ms. Miers didn't satisfy those who wanted to pack the Supreme Court with rigid ideologies.
The Judiciary Committee's ranking Democrat, Patrick Leahy, insisted his party was not to blame for Miers' withdrawal.
It all came from Republican newspeople, Republican columnists and Republicans in the Senate.

And even though the Republican chair of the Judiciary panel, Arlen Specter, had rejected Miers' answers to a questionnaire and disputed what she told him behind closed doors, he lashed out at what he called the heavy decibel level against her.
This is a sad episode in the history of Washington, DC, which has a lot of sad episodes, but the way Harriet Miers has been treated is really disgraceful.
Unidentified Girl #2: I didn't like cheese.
I think it's good idea because during the, you know, during the winter, everybody's got a cold or a sniffle, and I think you can get a lot of these germs from carts.
Do you think that people are getting a little too germophobic?
Shopper, Chevy Chase Supermarket): You know, I'm thinking we're getting a little carried away.
I mean, we've lived a while, and we're still here.
(Soundbite of music)
Sisters Betty Davis and Sue Holmes, plus Gerard Sheeny.
